title: Is it possible that life was formed in outer space and then came to earth? - Quora

response.answer_text: It is doubtful that life could spawn in outer space but it could have developed on another world and then been transported to Earth. There is a radical theory called panspermia which states that life developed on Mars, was struck by an asteroid, and pieces of the planet were hurled into space that made their way to Earth. Primitive organisms survived to seed our planet with life. Meteorite ALH84001, is believed to have once been a part of Mars and to contain fossil evidence that primitive life may have existed on Mars more than 3.6 billion years ago. The rock is a portion of a meteorite that was dislodged from Mars by a huge impact about 16 million years ago and land fell on Antarctica 13,000 years ago. The meteorite was found in the Allan Hills ice field, Antarctica, by an annual expedition of the National Science Foundation's Antarctic Meteorite Program in 1984. It is preserved for study at the Johnson Space Center's Meteorite Processing Laboratory in Houston.  There is also a hint of biological organism in this meteorite and features that resemble bacteria.  Another theory suggests that the building blocks for life came from space on board asteroids and comets.

That is definitely one of the proposed possibilities. Another is it could have first started on Mars and then an asteroid kicked a piece of rock that somehow ended up on earth. I’m in that camp that believes God is the author of DNA. Seriously, DNA, and RNA before it, is incredible. It is far more complex than a silicon based computer. It simply isn’t possible for me to fathom random chance pulling together an RNA based life form. And without RNA you don’t have evolution. But I haven’t studied the various first life theories in a couple decades. At that time they really weren’t worth much consideration.

It’s possible, but it’s not very likely. Amino acids form in space and rain down on us by the ton, but the few chemical precusors to life that we have identified need a protected, planetary environment in which to occur, and an extended era of relative stability to permit the slow process of pre-biological chemical evolution to produce the first cells. It does seem likely the life will apear anywhere conditions allow, but those condictions are not in space.

Is it possible to prove/infer life on Earth from outer space? One way, which works at a rather long way away, is to make a spectrographic analysis of the atmosphere. Any alien would then see that Earth’s atmosphere contains about 20% free oxygen. Oxygen does not like being free. It likes to oxidise. It likes to be rust, CO2, water, silicon oxide, anything but free oxygen. So if there is free oxygen, something is happening that replenishes the supply, or it would be long gone. If you are a wee bit closer, like in orbit (which is in outer space: it begins above the Kárman line, which is 100 km up), is to look out the window on the night side.  That doesn’t look that much like natural light, neither fires, volcanic eruption or weather phenomena.

Yes, It's possible. We have already seen some bacteria that survive under extreme conditions like heat, cold, Radiation from sun, extreme atmospheric pressure and can go dormant for millions of years, if conditions are not in its favour. They become active, if everything in their favor. They may have come to Earth from Mars or another World traveling for millions of years on Asteroids. Earth took lot of hitting from Asteroids since its birth.

Is it possible to prove/infer life on Earth from outer space? Depends on how good your telescope is. If you can see the colors of the continents (beyond the clouds) the change of seasons should be visible. But if you can see that, you should be able to see the lights of civilization, too. So either way. From further away, an analysis of the chemicals in the atmosphere might prove there’s life. There’s certainly a lot of strange chemicals there, so if they are detected, that should indicate our presence. Otherwise, a good radio-telescope could pick up our broadcasts. The “broadcast envelope” is close to a hundred light years out, although the power of the signals would be decreasing the further out you go and you’d need a really good receiver to pick up the Chase and Sanborn show staring Egar Bergen and Charlie McCarthy (and only be 78 light years away).
Sure it is possible. We find simple RNA in space, and plenty of organic molecules too. Life, as complex as humans, has been possible in this Universe for at least 8 billion years.
life may have been formed in outer space nothing can dispute it - life is a natural law the existing matter in the Universe - it will appear whenever and wherever its conditions are met.
